Award.AbstractNarration: Dr. Joshua Miller will travel to Fairbanks, Alaska for a week to meet with potential mentors and collaborators at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks and at state and federal agencies. The overall goal of his travel is to solidify the research goals and mentorship structure of a proposal, tentatively entitled Antlers of the Arctic: Landscape bone accumulations as a source of historical ecological and biogeographic data on caribou calving grounds, for submisstion to OPPs Postdoctoral Fellowships in Polar Regions Research program. He will present a seminar, engage in individual and group meetings, tour several laboratory facilities, and also meet with personnel at the Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program to discuss ways of incorporating students of native descent into his proposed research program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was a Polar Programs Postdoctoral Fellowship Travel Grant, which provides young researchers the opportunity to meet new and potential future collaborators as they develop their research ideas into a Polar Programs Postdoctoral Fellowship proposal. This award provided me the opportunity to travel to Alaska to meet with federal and state land and wildlife managers (Fish and Wildlife Service, National Parks Service, Bureau of Land Management, Alaska Department of Fish and Game) as well as academic scientists at the University of Alaska Fairbanks and the Large Animal Research Station. These meetings were conducted to obtain feedback on my proposed research activities in Arctic Alaska; reconstructing historical caribou calving grounds using bone and antler accumulations.

            Along with meetings with nearly twenty scientist, I gave a seminar on my past and proposed future research, hosted by the Biology department at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF). This not only provided an opportunity to reach a broader spectrum of the science community at UAF, but allowed me to talk to students within the program; I later met with a number of interested students about my future research goals and the role students could play in my work. I am also deeply interested in offering quality research experiences to undergraduate students (especially those from underrepresented groups); to that end I discussed the possibility of sponsoring two research internships for native Alaskan students at UAF through the Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program. Similarly, I also spent significant time discussing how my work could help develop new and effective ways of more fully integrating Traditional Ecological Knowledge (knowledge of plant and animal systems held by native/first nations peoples) into state and federal wildlife management efforts.

            One of the exciting prospects of my research into historical wildlife populations is that it would closely involve the state and federal research scientist who monitor the current populations. Thus, while my research would be developing a new tool for uncovering information on historical animal communities, it could be directly integrated into larger state and federal management activities, as well as land-use and wildlife policy. Additionally, this work has strong ramifications for paleobiology, archeology, physical anthropology, and forensic science – any field concerned with deciphering the biological, ecological, and behavioral data contained in bones sitting on landscape surfaces.

            My discussions and meetings went very well and I left Alaska with stronger relationships with a number of different groups of scientists – relationships that I have continued to develop. The opportunities provided by this award have been of great importance as I continue to develop and pursue my new research program.
